title: setting PYTHONPATH to the stage directory
body:
It looks like there is no way to export PYTHONPATH to a directory
inside the stage directory.  I think there's a timing issue between
setup_environment and the stage dir.

I'm writing a spack recipe for XED (Intel's x86 Encoder-Decoder).
XED uses its own python-based build system (mbuild) that lives in a
separate repository.

I can use a spack resource to clone the mbuild repo, but that kinda
puts the mbuild directory in the wrong place.  XED expects mbuild, by
default, to be in a side-by-side (sibling) directory.

Q1 -- Is it possible to put a spack resource somewhere other than as a
subdir of the main directory, in this case side-by-side?  I tried
resource with destination='../mbuild', but spack barfs at that.
Or, could I symlink it?

Anyway, XED will work with mbuild in any location, as long as you set
PYTHONPATH to the right directory.  I tried setup_environment() to set
PYTHONPATH.  But here, PYTHONPATH needs to be a subdir of the stage
dir and the stage dir is not known during setup_environment.  Inside
setup_environment, self.stage.source_path is None.

Q2 -- Is there a way to identify the stage dir in setup_environment?
I don't need the directory to exist, I just need to know the right
path name.

Q3 -- Or, is there somewhere later, after the stage dir is created
when I can set PYTHONPATH and it would be used in install?

I tried os.putenv('PYTHONPATH', ...) inside install, but that didn't
take effect.  I guess python had already read its environ variables
and didn't notice the change.  Is there a way to tell python to reread
its environment variables?

If absolutely necessary, I could make mbuild a separate, prereq
package.  The I could set PYTHONPATH to the mbuild prefix and it would
be known during setup_environment.

But that's overkill and what I really want is to set PYTHONPATH to
something in the stage directory.  It just looks like the spack timing
doesn't give me a way to do that.

Thanks,

--Mark
